New Records: Canada recorded their first-ever T20 World Cup win.
This was the first time in five innings that a team had managed to breach the 100-run mark in New York this World Cup.
Key Match Events: Nicholas Kirton and Shreyas Movva steadied the ship to take Canada to 137 for 7 in their 20 overs.
Jeremy Gordon and Dilon Heyliger held their own at the death to deliver Canada a famous win.
Mark Adair and George Dockrell put on 62 for the seventh wicket for Ireland.
Jeremy Gordon's relentless lengths got the better of Paul Stirling in the final over of the powerplay.
Saad Bin Zafar and Junaid Siddiqui applied the squeeze in the middle overs.
Lorcan Tucker ran himself out in the 10th over.
Aaron Johnson took a lovely catch at deep backward square leg diving to his left to dismiss Curtis Campher.
Gordon had 16 runs to defend in the final over and did it expertly.
Dockrell mistimed his heave to long-on off the final ball, leading to celebrations in the Canada dugout.
Post-Match Reflections: Niall O'Brien commented that Ireland should have restricted Canada to 115-120.
Niall O'Brien also remarked that there is a bit of Lara about Kirton.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The surface in New York was uneven and the outfield sluggish, making the chase of 138 tricky.
Canada's defence did not get off to the best of starts with Kaleem Sana unable to control the early movement.
Canada's bowlers followed Gordon's lead in understanding the lengths to bowl on the surface.
Ireland could only manage two fours in the first six overs.
The surface seemed to slow up a touch in the second half, benefiting the Canadian spinners.
